data.text: The Experience of Bike Travelers with Intermittent Fasting and Low Carb Diet

I would like to know the experience of other bike travelers with intermittent fasting and low carb diet. I know it is an odd question for this group, but because I think this way of eating could be especially useful for long, multi-day and remote trips, I opted this is the best place to ask I notice with myself if I bike some hours first before I stop to have breakfast I have the feeling I have moe energy, even before the breakfast. I noticed this before the intermittent fasting was hyped so I think it's not only in my head and I would like to hear other experiences with this. The next part is influenced by the hype and some books I've read. Since some months I started eating as little as possible added sugar, even during biking. Before I started this I actually did the opposite, but now I have the feeling that eating a salad during the ride gives me more energy than eating special sports energy bars. So I'd like to know if there are others that also avoid sugar during their trips.
If it works, stick with it
data.author: Angelos Kiosklis

data.text: When I am riding fasted and burning fat + carbs (not in ketosis), I have even energy and can go on for hours in that state. I don't have extra energy, I have uniform energy. I do feel it when my glycogen stores run out, though, on occasion, so you need to understand yourself, your food intake and the amount of energy you are expending. Also, refined sugar can be very useful when cycling in extreme cold weather; it will get you to where you are going if you get run down and need an almost instant pick me up.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: If your going to go bike touring, I'd have to say that you should be carbohydrate loading. That means plenty of carbs. Protien is good- it provides long lasting energy. But its not very good at providing energy that your body needs straight away. When I refer to carbs by the way - I'm not referring to refined white sugar white flour and the rest. More I'm referring to whole grains- brown rice, quinoa, millet and etc. Good carbs that add energy and nutrients, fibre, etc, to the body. I'd be careful about cutting carbs, particularly if you are going to go touring
data.author: Wayne Ostler

data.text: carbo loading is building up before a competition day, so that's not possible to do during bike touring.
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: what I’m saying is- I don’t think it’s a good idea to avoid carbs when you needing a lot of fuel to burn. And again I’m not talking about Simple sugars either- I’m talking more complex carbs
data.author: Wayne Ostler

data.text: if you need instant energy that is surely true, but since you need to keep your heart rate relatively low, with a balanced diet you could avoid needing instant energy. Most food have carbs in them already, so I'm also not talking about removing carbs completely.
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: Absolutely. Fat is a great power source even if carbs are absent. I prefer vegetable fat like avocados and bananas. Nuts.
data.author: Jörg Duurkoop

data.text: Hmmm… bananas… there is about 0,3g of fat in 100 g of a banana. Bananas are mainly carbohydrates (plus a good source of fiber)…
data.author: Piotr Buraczewski

data.text: I know. I'm not anti carb. Just prefer keto.
data.author: Jörg Duurkoop

data.text: At my age (59), i have to cut on sugar and i did so a year ago. I will soon start a long ride and i think i will be able to eat more sugary stuff. But now I don't have crave for sugar so I will observe the effect of eating no sugar vs eating some. I would not be surprise to have more energey when not eating sugar and also when not eating at all (or just a little). So much we don't know about the impact of food on our body. And it's different for each individual, we can't make generality.
data.author: Paul Mailhiot

data.text: I hope Apple implement in the Apple Watch 8 the function of reading blood sugar level. Knowing instantly the effect of a food on the sugar level will help on deciding what is best for me. I think....
data.author: Paul Mailhiot

data.text: I do agree fats and no sugar is a great way for energy, but for this to really work you need to be adjusted to this type of diet for a while. It doesn't work if you just decide to do it for just a couple days.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: very true. The first week of my turnaround was very difficult. Actually beforehand I couldn't even stand eating fat during and right before biking, I really needed carbs, but I needed to fuel all the time once I started eating during the ride.
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: I stopped eating sugar a long time ago, only honey and natural sugar in fruits are OK. I found that I don't like sugar any more except for an occasional bite of very dark chocolate.
data.author: Jörg Duurkoop

data.text: Follow. I am 55y old and like to loose 10 kg.
data.author: John Jensen

data.text: What I do is after my 6pm meal..I don't eat again til 1pm or 3pm the next day, one day a week, just water or instant juice. That with biking I lost a lot of weight from 215 to 180 target weight. But that's me. I experiment on me to know me better.🤗
data.author: Jai Cee

data.text: do you also dothis during periods of all-day biking?
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: never on all day biking you need the nutrient replacement on loooong runs..
data.author: Jai Cee

data.text: I think those things are great for the average person but do not see how this could be beneficial for a long or multi day ride. Carbs and sugar are instant energy. If your really rising the whole day I find it much more beneficial for my ride if I am constantly putting down high carb content foods and sugar during the ride along with hydration. With that said, once my ride is done and I am settled for the day I focus on protein to rebuild any muscle loss from the vigorous exercise.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: do you find the sugar means your blood sugar crashes and you need constant food? So you need to keep topping up to either prevent the sugar crash or stop it as its coming back down quickly? Just curious, Ive tried all sorts of different foods, and be good to have all experiences
data.author: Noon Kemp

data.text: I don't normally eat like this unless on a long ride and yes there is a crash at the end of the day but in the end it makes for a good night rest when your outdoors. I have been trying to think of things to start eating towards the last hour or so of my rides to help balance things out but not sure what the best thing is yet.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Depends on how intensely you push yourself. A really gentle but long ride could probably power on mostly fat. But if there are any hills or head-wind, then some carbs are needed. I find that I need to get close to the 5000 calorie/day to feel energized. I am already under-weight, so I can't afford to lose any precious body-mass
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Yes, what Wayne Ostler said. I’m 74 and have toured and raced 85,000+ miles over the last 30 years. In that time I I’ve tried to analyze what works. Nuts, carrots, and PB&J (or honey) sandwiches are high on my list. Fasting is questionable — my opinion is that a little hunger-suffering might train your body to use stored fats.
data.author: Rod Wanker

data.text: Interesting question. I used to do endurance mountain bike racing, 24 hour races over hilly terrain, we never stopped talking about food, and am now cycling around the world. I struggle to eat first thing so tend to eat little and often the first few hours, after that i don't really feel hungry but i know i feel more energetic after eating. What we eat is driven by what's available but generally start with carbs.. Oats nuts and dried fruit. Snack on trail mix. Have mix of carbs and protein for lunch and evening meal. Try and avoid sugar loaded food but find some times nothing quite works as well as a handful of sweets! Feeling hydrated is often our issue even tho we feel we drink enough. An orange or grapefruit really helps with that. Sorry not sure if my comments any use at all!
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: I have exactly the same experiences as you during multi-day trips: first cycling and only when I get a bit hungry, I have breakfast. In addition, I avoid added sugars and I prefer to eat products with slow carbohydrates. So bread instead of an energy bar and rice instead of pasta. I know that pasta likes to be eaten by cyclists, but after a few hours I get hungry again or the next morning I start with a hungry feeling. So no pasta and absolutely no (added) sugar for me! If I eat too much sugar, my blood sugar level first rises enormously and shortly after that a huge drop. So much so that I start shaking and have to eat something. With slow carbohydrates, vegetables, dairy and sometimes some meat (but preferably vegetarian) my blood sugar level remains at a constant level.
data.author: Gea Van Veen

data.text: that really sounds exactly like my experience.
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: And I thought I was the only one, because I often hear cyclists say they can eat anything!
data.author: Gea Van Veen

data.text: 👍🏻 same to me
data.author: Sylke Muzyk

data.text: Low carb / IF may make sense. Check also Jeff Volek for instance.
data.author: Gilles Nejman

data.text: I added him to my reading list 👌 probably my literature for during my bike trip next week.
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: Nuts, avocados and peanut butter work for me as snacks. I find it important to either have more complex carbs like oats for breakfast, or plenty of protein - so eggs and avocado are a great start to the day. I feel I get more energy out of protein and can last longer before feeling hungry than if I eat a more carb based breakfast. If you’re cutting carbs a lot (eg no oats or brown bread even) then just be super careful to make sure you’re getting enough fibre - sooooo important for bowel health
data.author: Anwen Ashworth

data.text: Dude, the salad gives you energy because of the potassium, magnesium, and other nutrients your body needs. I experience the same. Intermittent fasting gives you a feeling of being more energetic because your body isn't pumping out insulin all day. Avoiding sugar should make you feel more energetic. Best of luck dude.
data.author: Hayder Al-Mohammad

data.text: The American guy made a video about it on GCN once

data.text: I did a five day bike tour and had a hefty dinner of lasagna, bread, and a salad after a 50 mile day. I was hungry for another dinner in a couple of hours. make sure you get enough calories.

data.text: My first meal is at 14:00 and yes I have noticed that I have more energie . I have been doing 18:6 since October

data.text: I personally enjoy a beer or two 😁
data.author: José Carvalho

data.text: Unless you are super DUPER organised, you will do IF even if you don't intend on doing so. Just be careful not to do it on a "hard" day because you will bonk, and that's not great. Sometimes you'll be in situations where you haven't planned very well, and, there's not much around. 🤞 Those places are few and far between. Top tip: If you can find nuts, dried fruit, bread and jam, you'll always be fine 😍

data.text: One thing i will treat myself with; ice cream 🍦

data.text: I’m so down with this philosophy of nutrition. I’m planning to start my rides fasted during my first tour as to accelerate the effects of fasting and get some of that sweet sweet autophagy happening!

data.text: In my experience you just have to eat what is available?

data.text: 🙀

data.text: Have a look through sites such as Diabetes UK or "The 8-week Blood Sugar Diet" to get further and more detailed information on reducing carbs/sugar and the use of 'clean' carbs such as salad, brocolli, cauliflower.
data.author: Neil T Gorton

data.text: Ive read a lot of books about it already. But I want to hear real life experiences. If they talk about sports and food in studies/books it's always about short sessions or marathon.
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: We have been cycling for almost 2 years now. After our last winter break we totally changed our diet. We don't eat any more pasta and we make our own bread made of nuts and seeds. Only problem is we need an oven to make it 😉We avoid added sugars. And we try to avoid carbs after our workout. It is an ongoing proces of changing eating habits. But if you try to make a difference every day you will get there.
data.author: Ben van Baardwijk

data.text: I've seen a YouTube video of an Indian bikepacker who makes bread without an oven. I'll look this evening if I can find it 🙂

data.text: I guess you can dig a hole in the earth and make it really hot inside. 🤣

data.author: Gert Mountana

data.author: Jewella C Miranda

data.text: This question seems nearly as absurd as asking about additional muscular/cardiovascular training and supplementation with vitamine-D. Or not. At least, when doing sports, the damaging oversupply with glucose is nearly impossible, and the cell-repairing autophagy sets on or is increased . Based on my knowledge about nutrition and exercise, and complying with the probably best books about them: HOW NOT TO DIE(T) by Greger and EXERCISED by Lieberman, I recommend for the average person: - keep a daily fasting time window of best at least 16h. That means practically eat once or twice a day only - don't eat snacks around the clock - abstain from sweets with a high glycemic index - don't eat at least 4 hours before going to sleep, better have substantial breakfast - complex carbs and plant-based food are best for health, fat-based or ketogenic diet does not work well long term, although it is best for treating diabetes initially. Additionally a longer fasting (at least 36 hours) might be done once a month. The very active sportsperson can of course deviate from these rules. So he can always eat a banana or so and eat three times a day, if a fasting period of 12 hours is kept.
data.author: Hans Grob

data.text: it's not that absurd to ask, because most people call me crazy for doing that 😅 as you can also see from some of the comments. But the people that tried it seam to have positive results. 👍 Thanks for the book tips, the things you say are the things I also read in the books I already know, but it's always nice to have the input of other doctors, so I will probably read/listen those books too
data.author: Gert Mountana

data.text: I meant it rhetorically. I had written first 'The question is ...' instead of 'seems'. One of the most important strategies to get better knowledge is asking the right questions, even if seeming counterintuitive.
data.author: Hans Grob

data.text: I wanted to hear of people that have experience with this kind of fasting during multiday rides, and those people are giving interesting feedback. I get very little "Facebook expert" feedbacks, so my question is the right question.

data.text: Agree with most of the comments. I have been on 18.6 fasting regime for a few years . I can do a 20k run without breakfast.. muscles and liver typically hold around 1800 calories, enough for 2 hrs exercise. Low GI carbs obviously better than refined . I always have some protien and carbs within 20 mins of a hard exercise
data.author: Mark Sippings
